highlights.para: This chapter describes how to use menus in the desktop.

sect1.title: Introduction to Menus
sect1.para: You can access all desktop functions through menus. The default panels contain menus, so you can use a combination of menus and panels to perform your tasks.
You can perform various actions on your menus, such as display the menu as a window and copy menu items to panels.
You can access the following menus from the desktop:

listitem.para: Global Menu: The Global Menu is your primary menu. You can access almost all of the applications, commands, and configuration options on your desktop from the Global Menu.
Main Menu: The Main Menu is a customized Global Menu. You can have many Main Menu buttons in your panels. The structure of the menus can be different in each Main Menu.
System menus: System menus contain the standard applications and standard applets that you can use on your desktop.
Favorites menu: You can add items that you use frequently to your Favorites menu, and organize the items into submenus.
Custom menus: A custom menu is a menu that you create.

sect1.para: You can also open menus from the desktop background. The Root menu enables you to navigate between windows and workspaces. For information on the Root menu, see Working With Windows. The Desktop Background menu enables you to perform desktop background-related tasks. For information on the Desktop Background menu, see Using the Nautilus Desktop.
All of these menus provide you with multiple ways to perform your tasks, and enable you to work in the way that you prefer.

sect1.title: Menu Features
sect1.para: Menus have standard features that you can use to perform actions on the menus. This section describes the structure of menus and the standard features of menus.

sect1.para: describes the features of menus.

entry.para: Feature
Description
Tear-off icon

The tear-off icon is a thin dashed line at the top of the menu. To change a menu into a separate window on your desktop, click on the tear-off icon. The menu window remains on your desktop, even if you point to another location on your desktop.
Menu title

The name of the menu. The menu title is at the top of the menu, followed by a separator line. You can right-click on the menu title to open a popup menu. The popup menu enables you to add the menu to a panel or to the Favorites menu.
Menu items
Menus can contain the following items:

listitem.para: Submenus
Launchers
Applets

entry.para: An arrow to the right of an item in a menu indicates that the item is a submenu. When you point to the submenu, the submenu opens and you can choose items from the submenu.
When you choose a launcher, the launcher starts an application or runs a command. When you choose an applet from a menu, the applet is added to a panel.
You can right-click on a launcher or applet to open a popup menu. The popup menu enables you to add the item to a panel or to the Favorites menu. For more information on the popup menu, see .

sect1.para: You can specify global preferences for all menus in the Control Center. For example, you can select an option to display large icons in your menus.

You can change the GNOME system settings for menu in the Panel capplet. The system settings for menus are displayed in the Menu tabbed section. You can also change the theme for your session to change how all your menus look. You can change the theme in the Theme Selector capplet.

sect2.title: Menu Item Popup Menus
sect2.para: Menu items have an associated popup menu that enables you to add the item to your panels and to your Favorites menu. When you right-click on the title of an item in a menu, the popup menu for the menu, launcher, or applet opens. This menu is different for menus, launchers, and applets.
You can use the popup menu to perform the following tasks:

listitem.para: Add menus, launchers, and applets to panels. You can add a menu as a menu object or as a drawer object.
Add submenus, launchers, and applets to your Favorites menu.
Remove submenus, launchers, and applets from your Favorites menu.
Change the properties of submenus, launchers, and applets in your Favorites menu.

sect2.para: Some items in the popup menu might not be available to you. Your user privileges determine which items are available. For example, if you do not have system administrator privileges, you can not modify the properties of the Programs menu.

sect1.title: Global Menu
sect1.para: The Global Menu is your primary menu. You can access almost all of the standard applications, commands, and configuration options on your desktop from the Global Menu.
The Global Menu provides the following top-level menus and special menu items:

listitem.para: Programs: Contains all applications and configuration tools. This menu also includes the file manager and GNOME Help Browser.
Favorites: You can add items that you use frequently to your Favorites menu, and organize the items into submenus.
Applets: Contains all applets that are installed on your system.
Run launcher: Displays the Run Program dialog.
Panel: Contains all commands that relate to panels.
Desktop: Contains the Lock screen and Log out menu items. By default, the items in the Desktop menu are at the top level of the Global Menu.

sect1.para: You can customize the Global Menu to help you work more efficiently. You can modify which menus are displayed on the Global Menu, and how the menus are displayed on the Global Menu. For example you can select to display all the items in the Programs menu at the top level of the Global Menu. You can customize the Global Menu in the Panel capplet.
You can add Global Menu buttons to your panels. By default, the Global Menu is represented on panels by a stylized footprint icon, as follows:

screenshot.screeninfo: Screenshot of the Global Menu icon

sect2.title: To Open the Global Menu
sect2.para: You can open the Global Menu in the following ways:

listitem.para: From a panel with a Global Menu
Click on the Global Menu.
From any panel
To open the Global Menu from a panel right-click on a vacant space in the panel. If there is no vacant space in the panel, right-click on one of the hide buttons.

If you want to use the Global Menu to perform actions on a panel, you must open the Global Menu from that panel. You can use the Global Menu to perform the following actions on a panel:
Add an item to the panel
Modify the properties of the panel
Remove the panel
Use a shortcut key
You can use a shortcut key to open the Global Menu. When you use a shortcut key to open the Global Menu, the Global Menu appears at the mouse pointer.

The default shortcut key to open the Global Menu is AltF1. You can change the shortcut key that opens the
Global Menu in the Panel capplet.

sect2.title: To Add a Global Menu to a Panel
sect2.para:
You can add as many Global Menu buttons as you want to your panels. To add a Global Menu to a panel, right-click on any vacant space on the panel to open the Global Menu. Choose
Panel Add to panel Menu Main menu .

sect2.title: To Change a Global Menu Icon
sect2.para: You can choose a custom icon to represent a Global Menu.
To choose a custom icon to represent a Global Menu perform the following steps:

listitem.para: Right-click on the Global Menu to open the panel object popup menu.
Choose Properties to display the Menu Properties dialog. Click on the Icon tab to display the Icon tabbed section.
Select the Use custom icon for panel button option.

Click on the icon selector button to display an icon selector dialog. Choose an icon from the dialog. Alternatively, click Browse to choose an icon from another directory. When you choose an icon, click OK.
Click Close.

sect2.title: To Modify How the Global Menu Displays Menus
sect2.para: To modify how the Global Menu displays menus perform the following steps:

listitem.para:
To start the Panel capplet open the Global Menu, then choose
Programs Settings Desktop Panel . Click on the Menu tab.
In the Global menu group, choose the appropriate setting for each menu, as follows:

entry.para: Option
Description
Select this option to place the items in the menu directly at the top level of the Global Menu.
Select this option to place the menu as a submenu on the Global Menu .
Select this option to exclude the menu from the Global Menu.

listitem.para: Click OK to save your changes.

sect1.title: Main Menu
sect1.para: The Main Menu is represented on panels as a stylized footprint icon. To open the Main Menu click on the Main Menu button.

The Main Menu provides the same menus and functions as the
Global Menu. The Main Menu differs from the Global Menu in the following ways:

listitem.para: A Main Menu button is a panel object. A Global Menu button is a panel object but you can also open the Global Menu from anywhere on the desktop.

You can have many Main Menu buttons in your panels. The structure of the menus can be different in each Main Menu. That is, you can select how particular menus are displayed in the menu. For example you can select to display all the items in the Programs menu at the top level of the Main Menu.
You can also have many Global Menu buttons in your panels, but the structure of the menus is exactly the same in each Global Menu.
To customize instances of a Main Menu you modify the properties of the Main Menu. To customize the Global Menu you use the Control Center.

sect2.title: To Add a Main Menu to a Panel
sect2.para:
You can add as many Main Menu buttons as you want to your panels. To add a Main Menu to a panel, right-click on any vacant space on the panel to open the Global Menu. Choose
Panel Add to panel Menu Main menu .

note.para: When you add a Main Menu button to a panel, the button is added as a Global Menu. To change the Global Menu to a Main Menu, right-click on the button to open the panel object popup menu. Choose Properties . On the Menu Properties dialog, select Main menu. Click Close.

sect2.para: You can customize each Main Menu on your panels to help you work more efficiently. For each Main Menu, you can specify the following:

listitem.para: The menus that are on the Main Menu.
Whether the menus are in a submenu on the Main Menu .

listitem.para: Right-click on the Main Menu to open the panel object popup menu.

sect1.title: System Menus
sect1.para: System menus contain the standard applications and standard applets that you can use on your desktop.
describes the system menus available on your desktop.

entry.para: Menu
Description

Contains all applications and configuration tools. The Programs menu contains a hierarchy of submenus such as Applications and Settings, from which you can start the standard GNOME applications and configuration tools. The Programs menu also includes the file manager and GNOME Help Browser.
The Programs menu resides in the following places:

listitem.para: Root menu
On the Menu Panel, in modified form

entry.para: The Applets menu contains all of the applets that are installed on your system. To add an applet to a panel open the Global Menu from the panel, then choose the applet from the Applets menu.
The Applets menu resides in the following places:

listitem.para: On the Menu Panel, in the Programs menu

sect1.para: Your system administrator specifies the contents of system menus. Typically, all users on a system have access to the system menus. The Programs menu corresponds to the $GNOME_BASEDIR/share/gnome/apps directory. The Applets menu corresponds to the $GNOME_BASEDIR/share/applets directory.

sect2.title: To Edit a System Menu
sect2.para: You can edit the contents of the system menus only if you have the appropriate system privileges. You can use the Menu Editor to edit the system menus. You can also open the system menus and right-click on menu items to open a popup menu that enables you to edit the system menus.

sect1.title: Favorites Menu
sect1.para: The Favorites menu resides in the following places:

listitem.para: Menu Panel

sect1.para: You can add items that you frequently use to your Favorites menu, and organize the items into submenus. Your Favorites menu contains only items that you add.

The Favorites menu contains items that are not shared, but are specific to each individual user. The Favorites menu corresponds to a directory in your private home directory, the ~/.gnome/apps directory. This structure contrasts with system menus, which are usually shared by many users and which reside in a public directory.

sect2.title: To Edit the Favorites Menu
sect2.para: You can use the Menu Editor to edit the contents of your Favorites menu. You can also open menus and right-click on menu items to open a popup menu that enables you to add items to the Favorites menu. If you right-click on a menu item in the Favorites menu, you can remove the item from the Favorites menu.

sect1.title: Custom Menus
sect1.para: A custom menu is menu that you create. You can create a custom menu in any directory to which you have write access. If you want to create a menu to share with other users, you can create a custom menu in a public location. You can then inform other users of the location of the custom menu. The other users can then open their file manager and drag the menu to their panels, where the menu is added as a menu object.
You must create a custom menu manually. To create a menu manually you must first understand the structure of menus, and their relationship to directories and special files.

sect2.title: To Create a Custom Menu
sect2.para: To create a custom menu follow these steps:

listitem.para: Create the directory for the menu. The name that you choose for the directory becomes the name of the menu.

Create a .directory file and a .order file for the menu, and add the files to the menu directory. You can copy the .directory file and .order files from another menu directory, then edit the files to suit your requirements.
Create .desktop files for the menu, and add the files to the menu directory. You can copy the .desktop files from another menu directory, then edit the files to suit your requirements.
Your menu is now complete. To add the menu to a panel drag the menu directory from your file manager to the panel.

tip.para: You can also use the Menu Editor to create a custom menu. Use the Menu Editor to create the custom menu in your Favorites menu. The Menu Editor creates the .order and .directory files. Move the custom menu structure to the required location.

sect2.title: To Edit a Custom Menu
sect2.para: If you have permissions to write to the custom menu files, you can open the custom menu and right-click on menu items to open a popup menu. The popup menu enables you to edit the custom menu.
You can also edit the custom menu manually. To edit a menu manually you must first understand the structure of menus on your desktop.

sect1.title: Menu Editor
sect1.para: This section describes how to edit your menus.

sect2.title: Introduction to the Menu Editor
sect2.para: You can use the Menu Editor to edit your menus. If you are a system administrator, you can use the Menu Editor to edit the system menus. If you are a normal user, you can use the Menu Editor to edit your Favorites menu.
You can use the Menu Editor to add the following items to your menus:

listitem.para: Submenus
Launchers
Applets

sect2.para: You can also add further items to your submenus. This feature enables you to create a hierarchical menu structure for your launchers and applets.

sect2.para: The Menu Editor contains the following elements:

entry.para: Element
Description
Menubar
Contains commands that you use to perform tasks in the Menu Editor. These commands are in the File, Sort, and Help menus.
Toolbar
Contains buttons that you use to perform tasks in the Menu Editor. For example, the toolbar contains New Submenu, New Item, and Delete buttons.
Menu tree pane
Displays the hierarchical structure of your menus. You can expand and collapse the menus in the menu tree pane.
You use the menu tree pane to select the menu that you want to edit.
The menu tree also includes a popup menu that you can use to perform tasks in the Menu Editor. To use this popup menu, right-click on the item that you want to edit, then choose a menu item.
Dialog pane
Contains a dialog with a Basic tabbed section and an Advanced tabbed section. Use this dialog to add and modify submenus and submenu items.
Comment statusbar
Displays information on the item selected in the menu tree. This information is usually the same as the Comment information for the item.
Directory statusbar
Displays the directory location of the item selected in the menu tree.
Resize button
Drag this button to resize the menu tree pane and dialog pane areas.

sect2.title: To Start the Menu Editor
sect2.para: To start the Menu Editor perform one of the following actions:

listitem.para:
Open the Global Menu. Choose
Programs Settings Menu editor .
Right-click on a Global Menu or a Main Menu to open a panel object popup menu. Choose Edit menus.

sect2.title: To Add a Submenu
sect2.para: To add a submenu perform the following steps:

listitem.para: In the menu tree, select the menu to which you want to add a submenu.

Choose
File New Submenu . A New Folder icon is added to the menu tree. A dialog for entering details of the new submenu is displayed in the dialog pane.
Enter the information for the submenu in the Basic tabbed section on the dialog pane. The following table describes the dialog elements on the Basic tabbed section:

entry.para: Dialog Element
Description
Use this text box to specify the name of the submenu. You can use the Advanced tabbed section to add translations of the name.

Use this text box to specify a short description of the submenu. The description is displayed as a tooltip when you point to the submenu icon. You can use the Advanced tabbed section to add translations of the short description.
Not required for a submenu.
The Type of a submenu must be Directory. You cannot change the Type of a submenu.

Choose an icon to represent the submenu. To choose an icon, click on the icon selector button. An icon selector dialog is displayed. Choose an icon from this dialog. Alternatively, to choose an icon from another directory, click Browse. When you choose an icon, click OK.
Not required for a submenu.

listitem.para: You can also add a translation of the Name and Comment information for the submenu. To add a translation, click on the Advanced tab. Enter the details of the translation in the Name/Comment translations table as follows:

entry.para: Field
Description
First field
Enter the two-letter code for the language for which you want to add a translation.
Second field
Enter the translation of the Name text box.
Third field
Enter the translation of the Comment text box.

listitem.para: Click on the Add/Set button.

To edit a translation, select the translation in the Name/Comment translations table. The translated text is displayed in the fields under the table. Edit the fields as required, then click on the Add/Set button.
To remove a translation, select the translation in the Name/Comment translations table, then click Remove.

note.para: The Try this before using text box and Documentation text box are not required for a submenu.

listitem.para: Click Save to save the details of the new submenu.
Alternatively, click Revert to return to your previously saved menu structure.

sect2.title: To Add an Item to a Submenu
sect2.para: To add an item to a submenu perform the following steps:

listitem.para: In the menu tree, select the menu to which you want to add the item.

Choose
File New Item . An untitled icon is added to the menu tree. A dialog where you can enter details of the new item is displayed in the dialog pane.
Enter the information for the item in the Basic tabbed section in the dialog pane. The following table describes the dialog elements on the Basic tabbed section:

entry.para: Dialog Element
Description
Use this text box to specify the name of the item. You can use the Advanced tab to add translations of the name.

Use this text box to specify a short description of the item. When you point to the item, the comment is displayed as a tooltip. You can use the Advanced tabbed section to add translations of the comment.
Enter the command to run when you choose the item. You can also enter a URL if you choose URL as the Type.
Choose from the following types of list item:

listitem.para: Application: Choose this list item for an application launcher.
PanelApplet: Choose this list item for an applet launcher.
URL: Choose this list item to create a launcher that opens an Internet browser at a particular URL.

entry.para: Choose an icon to represent the item. To choose an icon, click on the Icon button. An icon selector dialog is displayed. Choose an icon from this dialog. Alternatively, to choose an icon from another directory, click Browse.
Select this option to run the application or command in a terminal window. Choose this option for an application or command that does not create a window in which to run.

listitem.para: Enter the advanced properties of the item in the dialog. The following table describes the fields on the top part of the Advanced tabbed section:

entry.para: Field
Description
Enter a command here for your system to try before starting the item. If the system can execute this command, the item is not displayed on the submenu.
This field is not currently in use.

listitem.para: You can also add a translation of the Name and Comment information for the item. To add a translation, click on the Advanced tab. Enter the details of the translation in the Name/Comment translations table as follows:

entry.para: Field
Description
First field
Enter the two-letter code for the language for which you want to add a translation.
Second field
Enter the translation of the Name of the item.
Third field
Enter the translation of the Comment for the item.

listitem.para: Then click on the Add/Set button.

To edit a translation, select the translation in the Name/Comment translations table. The translated text is displayed in the fields under the table. Make your edits in the fields, then click on the Add/Set button.
To remove a translation, select the translation in the Name/Comment translations table, then click Remove.
Click Save to save the details of the new item.
Alternatively, click Revert to return to your previously saved menu.

sect2.title: To Modify a Submenu or Submenu Item
sect2.para: To modify a submenu or submenu item perform the following steps:

listitem.para: In the menu tree, select the menu or menu item that you want to modify. The details of the menu or menu item are displayed in the dialog pane.
In the dialog pane, modify the dialog elements.
Click Save to save your changes to the submenu.
Alternatively, click Revert to undo your changes.

sect2.title: To Move a Submenu or Submenu Item
sect2.para: To move a submenu or submenu item perform one of the following actions:

listitem.para: To move the submenu or submenu item to another menu, drag the submenu or submenu item to the new location in the menu tree.

To move the submenu or submenu item within a menu, select the menu that you want to move. Click on the Move up or Move down toolbar buttons to move the item. Repeat this step until the submenu or item is in the new location.

sect2.title: To Delete a Submenu or Submenu Item
sect2.para:
To delete a submenu or submenu item, select the item that you want to delete in the menu tree. Choose
File Delete . The item is deleted from the menu.

sect2.title: To Sort a Submenu
sect2.para: The Menu Editor includes commands that enable you to sort your menus alphabetically. You can sort the items in a particular menu. You can also sort menus recursively. In other words, you can sort all of the submenus and submenu items that a menu contains.

To sort a submenu, select the menu that you want to sort in the menu tree. Choose
Sort Sort Submenu . To perform a recursive sort, choose
Sort Sort Submenu Recursive .

sect2.title: To Quit the Menu Editor
sect2.para:
To quit the Menu Editor, choose
File Exit .
